query: How to benchmark Redis performance? What tool should I use?
answer:
Based on the knowledge base, here's how to benchmark Redis performance:

## Primary Tool: redis-benchmark

Redis includes a built-in utility called `redis-benchmark` that simulates running commands by N clients sending M total queries (similar to Apache's `ab` utility).

### Basic Usage

```bash
redis-benchmark -q -n 100000
```

### Key Options

- `-h <hostname>` - Server hostname (default 127.0.0.1)
- `-p <port>` - Server port (default 6379)
- `-c <clients>` - Number of parallel connections (default 50)
- `-n <requests>` - Total number of requests (default 100000)
- `-d <size>` - Data size of SET/GET value in bytes (default 3)
- `-t <tests>` - Only run specific tests (comma-separated)
- `-P <numreq>` - Pipeline requests (default 1, no pipeline)
- `-q` - Quiet mode, just show query/sec values
- `--threads <num>` - Enable multi-thread mode

### Example: Test Specific Commands

```bash
redis-benchmark -t set,lpush -n 100000 -q
```

### Example: Using Pipelining (Higher Throughput)

```bash
redis-benchmark -n 1000000 -t set,get -P 16 -q
```

Pipelining can dramatically improve performance (e.g., from ~72K to 1.5M+ requests/sec for SET operations).

## Alternative Third-Party Tools

1. **memtier_benchmark** (Redis Labs) - NoSQL Redis and Memcache traffic generation and benchmarking tool
   - GitHub: https://github.com/redislabs/memtier_benchmark

2. **rpc-perf** (Twitter) - Benchmarking tool for RPC services supporting Redis and Memcache
   - GitHub: https://github.com/twitter/rpc-perf

3. **YCSB** (Yahoo) - Benchmarking framework with clients for many databases including Redis
   - GitHub: https://github.com/brianfrankcooper/YCSB

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/optimization/benchmarks/index.md > How fast is Redis? + Other Redis benchmarking tools]

\\"Other Redis benchmarking tools\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"It is critically important that Redis performance is retained or improved seamlessly on every released version. \\\\n\\\\nTo assess it, we\'ve conducted benchmarks on the released versions of Redis (starting on v2.6.0) using `redis-benchmark` on a series of command types over a standalone redis-server, repeating the same benchmark multiple times, ensuring its statistical significance, and measuring the run-to-run variance.\\\\n\\\\nThe used hardware platform was a stable bare-metal HPE ProLiant DL380 Gen10 Server, with one Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 6230 CPU @ 2.10GHz, disabling Intel HT Technology, disabling CPU Frequency scaling, with all configurable BIOS and CPU system settings set to performance. \\\\n\\\\nThe box was running Ubuntu 18.04 Linux release 4.15.0-123, and Redis was compiled with gcc 7.5.0.\\\\nThe used benchmark client (`redis-benchmark`) was kept stable across all tests, with version `redis-benchmark 6.2.0 (git:445aa844)`.\\\\nBoth the redis-server and redis-benchmark processes were pinned to specific physical cores.\\\\n\\\\nThe following benchmark options were used across tests:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* The tests were done with 50 simultaneous clients performing 5 million requests.\\\\n* Tests were executed using the loopback interface.\\\\n* Tests were executed without pipelining.\\\\n* The used payload size was 256 Bytes.\\\\n* For each redis-benchmark process, 2 threads were used to ensure that the benchmark client was not the bottleneck.\\\\n* Strings, Hashes, Sets, and Sorted Sets data types were benchmarked.\\\\n\\\\nBelow we present the obtained results, broken by data type.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n![Strings performance over versions](./performance-strings.png)\\\\n\\\\n![Hashes performance over versions](./performance-hashes.png)\\\\n\\\\n![Sets performance over versions](./performance-sets.png)\\\\n\\\\n![Sorted sets performance over versions](./performance-sorted-sets.png)\\\\n\\\\nThere are several third-party tools that can be used for benchmarking Redis. Refer to each tool\'s\\\\ndocumentation for more information about its goals and capabilities.\\\\n\\\\n* [memtier_benchmark](https://github.com/redislabs/memtier_benchmark) from [Redis Labs](https://twitter.com/RedisLabs) is a NoSQL Redis and Memcache traffic generation and benchmarking tool.\\\\n* [rpc-perf](https://github.com/twitter/rpc-perf) from [Twitter](https://twitter.com/twitter) is a tool for benchmarking RPC services that supports Redis and Memcache.\\\\n* [YCSB](https://github.com/brianfrankcooper/YCSB) from [Yahoo @Yahoo](https://twitter.com/Yahoo) is a benchmarking framework with clients to many databases, including Redis.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 3.8209,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"fc275d19\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"fc275d19-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/management/optimization/benchmarks/index.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redis benchmark\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"How fast is Redis?\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Redis includes the `redis-benchmark` utility that simulates running commands done\\\\nby N clients at the same time sending M total queries (it is similar to the\\\\nApache\'s `ab` utility). Below you\'ll find the full output of a benchmark executed\\\\nagainst a Linux box.\\\\n\\\\nThe following options are supported:\\\\n\\\\n    Usage: redis-benchmark [-h <host>] [-p <port>] [-c <clients>] [-n <requests]> [-k <boolean>]\\\\n\\\\n     -h <hostname>      Server hostname (default 127.0.0.1)\\\\n     -p <port>          Server port (default 6379)\\\\n     -s <socket>        Server socket (overrides host and port)\\\\n     -a <password>      Password for Redis Auth\\\\n     --user <username>  Used to send ACL style \'AUTH username pass\'. Needs -a.\\\\n     -c <clients>       Number of parallel connections (default 50)\\\\n     -n <requests>      Total number of requests (default 100000)\\\\n     -d <size>          Data size of SET/GET value in bytes (default 3)\\\\n     --dbnum <db>       SELECT the specified db number (default 0)\\\\n     --threads <num>    Enable multi-thread mode.\\\\n     --cluster          Enable cluster mode.\\\\n     --enable-tracking  Send CLIENT TRACKING on before starting benchmark.\\\\n     -k <boolean>       1=keep alive 0=reconnect (default 1)\\\\n     -r <keyspacelen>   Use random keys for SET/GET/INCR, random values for\\\\n                        SADD, random members and scores for ZADD.\\\\n                        Using this option the benchmark will expand the string\\\\n                        __rand_int__ inside an argument with a 12 digits number\\\\n                        in the specified range from 0 to keyspacelen-1. The\\\\n                        substitution changes every time a command is executed.\\\\n                        Default tests use this to hit random keys in the\\\\n                        specified range.\\\\n     -P <numreq>        Pipeline <numreq> requests. Default 1 (no pipeline).\\\\n     -e                 If server replies with errors, show them on stdout.\\\\n                        (No more than 1 error per second is displayed.)\\\\n     -q                 Quiet. Just show query/sec values\\\\n     --precision        Number of decimal places to display in latency output (default 0)\\\\n     --csv              Output in CSV format\\\\n     -l                 Loop. Run the tests forever\\\\n     -t <tests>         Only run the comma separated list of tests. The test\\\\n                        names are the same as the ones produced as output.\\\\n     -I                 Idle mode. Just open N idle connections and wait.\\\\n     --help             Output this help and exit.\\\\n     --version          Output version and exit.\\\\n\\\\nYou need to have a running Redis instance before launching the benchmark.\\\\nA typical example would be:\\\\n\\\\n    redis-benchmark -q -n 100000\\\\n\\\\nUsing this tool is quite easy, and you can also write your own benchmark,\\\\nbut as with any benchmarking activity, there are some pitfalls to avoid.\\\\n\\\\nRunning only a subset of the tests\\\\n---\\\\n\\\\nYou don\'t need to run all the default tests every time you execute redis-benchmark.\\\\nThe simplest thing to select only a subset of tests is to use the `-t` option\\\\nlike in the following example:\\\\n\\\\n    $ redis-benchmark -t set,lpush -n 100000 -q\\\\n    SET: 180180.17 requests per second, p50=0.143 msec                    \\\\n    LPUSH: 188323.91 requests per second, p50=0.135 msec\\\\n\\\\nIn the above example we asked to just run test the SET and LPUSH commands,\\\\nin quiet mode (see the `-q` switch).\\\\n\\\\nIt is also possible to specify the command to benchmark directly like in the\\\\nfollowing example:\\\\n\\\\n    $ redis-benchmark -n 100000 -q script load \\\\\\"redis.call(\'set\',\'foo\',\'bar\')\\\\\\"\\\\n    script load redis.call(\'set\',\'foo\',\'bar\'): 69881.20 requests per second\\\\n\\\\nSelecting the size of the key space\\\\n---\\\\n\\\\nBy default the benchmark runs against a single key. In Redis the difference\\\\nbetween such a synthetic benchmark and a real one is not huge since it is an\\\\nin-memory system, however it is possible to stress cache misses and in general\\\\nto simulate a more real-world work load by using a large key space.\\\\n\\\\nThis is obtained by using the `-r` switch. For instance if I want to run\\\\none million SET operations, using a random key for every operation out of\\\\n100k possible keys, I\'ll use the following command line:\\\\n\\\\n    $ redis-cli flushall\\\\n    OK\\\\n\\\\n    $ redis-benchmark -t set -r 100000 -n 1000000\\\\n    ====== SET ======\\\\n      1000000 requests completed in 13.86 seconds\\\\n      50 parallel clients\\\\n      3 bytes payload\\\\n      keep alive: 1\\\\n\\\\n    99.76% `<=` 1 milliseconds\\\\n    99.98% `<=` 2 milliseconds\\\\n    100.00% `<=` 3 milliseconds\\\\n    100.00% `<=` 3 milliseconds\\\\n    72144.87 requests per second\\\\n\\\\n    $ redis-cli dbsize\\\\n    (integer) 99993\\\\n\\\\nUsing pipelining\\\\n---\\\\n\\\\nBy default every client (the benchmark simulates 50 clients if not otherwise\\\\nspecified with `-c`) sends the next command only when the reply of the previous\\\\ncommand is received, this means that the server will likely need a read call\\\\nin order to read each command from every client. Also RTT is paid as well.\\\\n\\\\nRedis supports [pipelining](/topics/pipelining), so it is possible to send\\\\nmultiple commands at once, a feature often exploited by real world applications.\\\\nRedis pipelining is able to dramatically improve the number of operations per\\\\nsecond a server is able to deliver.\\\\n\\\\nThis is an example of running the benchmark in a MacBook Air 11\\\\\\" using a\\\\npipelining of 16 commands:\\\\n\\\\n    $ redis-benchmark -n 1000000 -t set,get -P 16 -q\\\\n    SET: 1536098.25 requests per second, p50=0.479 msec                     \\\\n    GET: 1811594.25 requests per second, p50=0.391 msec\\\\n\\\\nUsing pipelining results in a significant increase in performance.\\\\n\\\\nPitfalls and misconceptions\\\\n---------------------------\\\\n\\\\nThe first point is obvious: the golden rule of a useful benchmark is to\\\\nonly compare apples and apples. Different versions of Redis can be compared\\\\non the same workload for instance. Or the same version of Redis, but with\\\\ndifferent options. If you plan to compare Redis to something else, then it is\\\\nimportant to evaluate the functional and technical differences, and take them\\\\nin account.\\\\n\\\\n+ Redis is a server, hence, all commands involve network round trips. Embedded data stores do not involve network and protocol management. When comparing such products to Redis, command execution times should be used instead of end-to-end times.\\\\n+ Redis commands return an acknowledgment for all usual commands. Some other data stores do not. Comparing Redis to stores involving one-way queries is only mildly useful.\\\\n+ Naively iterating on synchronous Redis commands does not benchmark Redis itself, but rather measure your network (or IPC) latency and the client library intrinsic latency. To really test Redis, you need multiple connections (like redis-benchmark) and/or to use pipelining to aggregate several commands and/or multiple threads or processes.\\\\n+ Redis is an in-memory data store with some optional persistence options. If you plan to compare it to transactional servers (MySQL, PostgreSQL, etc ...), then you should consider activating AOF and decide on a suitable fsync policy.\\\\n+ Redis is, mostly, a single-threaded server from the POV of commands execution (actually modern versions of Redis use threads for different things). It is not designed to benefit from multiple CPU cores. People are supposed to launch several Redis instances to scale out on several cores if needed. It is not really fair to compare one single Redis instance to a multi-threaded data store.\\\\n\\\\nA common misconception is that redis-benchmark is designed to make Redis\\\\nperformances look stellar, the throughput achieved by redis-benchmark being\\\\nsomewhat artificial, and not achievable by a real application. This is\\\\nactually not true.\\\\n\\\\nThe `redis-benchmark` program is a quick and useful way to get some figures and\\\\nevaluate the performance of a Redis instance on a given hardware. However,\\\\nby default, it does not represent the maximum throughput a Redis instance can\\\\nsustain. Actually, by using pipelining and a fast client (hiredis), it is fairly\\\\neasy to write a program generating more throughput than redis-benchmark. The\\\\ndefault behavior of redis-benchmark is to achieve throughput by exploiting\\\\nconcurrency only (i.e. it creates several connections to the server).\\\\nIt does not use pipelining or any parallelism at all (one pending query per\\\\nconnection at most, and no multi-threading), if not explicitly enabled via\\\\nthe `-P` parameter. So in some way using `redis-benchmark` and, triggering, for\\\\nexample, a `BGSAVE` operation in the background at the same time, will provide\\\\nthe user with numbers more near to the *worst case* than to the best case.\\\\n\\\\nTo run a benchmark using pipelining mode (and achieve higher throughput),\\\\nyou need to explicitly use the -P option. Please note that it is still a\\\\nrealistic behavior since a lot of Redis based applications actively use\\\\npipelining to improve performance. However you should use a pipeline size that\\\\nis more or less the average pipeline length you\'ll be able to use in your\\\\napplication in order to get realistic numbers.\\\\n\\\\nFinally, the benchmark should apply the same operations, and work in the same way\\\\nwith the multiple data stores you want to compare. It is absolutely pointless to\\\\ncompare the result of redis-benchmark to the result of another benchmark\\\\nprogram and extrapolate.\\\\n\\\\nFor instance, Redis and memcached in single-threaded mode can be compared on\\\\nGET/SET operations. Both are in-memory data stores, working mostly in the same\\\\nway at the protocol level. Provided their respective benchmark application is\\\\naggregating queries in the same way (pipelining) and use a similar number of\\\\nconnections, the comparison is actually meaningful.\\\\n\\\\nThis perfect example is illustrated by the dialog between Redis (antirez) and\\\\nmemcached (dormando) developers.\\\\n\\\\n[antirez 1 - On Redis, Memcached, Speed, Benchmarks and The Toilet](http://antirez.com/post/redis-memcached-benchmark.html)\\\\n\\\\n[dormando - Redis VS Memcached (slightly better bench)](http://dormando.livejournal.com/525147.html)\\\\n\\\\n[antirez 2 - An update on the Memcached/Redis benchmark](http://antirez.com/post/update-on-memcached-redis-benchmark.html)\\\\n\\\\nYou can see that in the end, the difference between the two solutions is not\\\\nso staggering, once all technical aspects are considered. Please note both\\\\nRedis and memcached have been optimized further after these benchmarks.\\\\n\\\\nFinally, when very efficient servers are benchmarked (and stores like Redis\\\\nor memcached definitely fall in this category), it may be difficult to saturate\\\\nthe server. Sometimes, the performance bottleneck is on client side,\\\\nand not server-side. In that case, the client (i.e. the benchmark program itself)\\\\nmust be fixed, or perhaps scaled out, in order to reach the maximum throughput.\\\\n\\\\nFactors impacting Redis performance\\\\n-----------------------------------\\\\n\\\\nThere are multiple factors having direct consequences on Redis performance.\\\\nWe mention them here, since they can alter the result of any benchmarks.\\\\nPlease note however, that a typical Redis instance running on a low end,\\\\nuntuned box usually provides good enough performance for most applications.\\\\n\\\\n+ Network bandwidth and latency usually have a direct impact on the performance.\\\\nIt is a good practice to use the ping program to quickly check the latency\\\\nbetween the client and server hosts is normal before launching the benchmark.\\\\nRegarding the bandwidth, it is generally useful to estimate\\\\nthe throughput in Gbit/s and compare it to the theoretical bandwidth\\\\nof the network. For instance a benchmark setting 4 KB strings\\\\nin Redis at 100000 q/s, would actually consume 3.2 Gbit/s of bandwidth\\\\nand probably fit within a 10 Gbit/s link, but not a 1 Gbit/s one. In many real\\\\nworld scenarios, Redis throughput is limited by the network well before being\\\\nlimited by the CPU. To consolidate several high-throughput Redis instances\\\\non a single server, it worth considering putting a 10 Gbit/s NIC\\\\nor multiple 1 Gbit/s NICs with TCP/IP bonding.\\\\n+ CPU is another very important factor. Being single-threaded, Redis favors\\\\nfast CPUs with large caches and not many cores. At this game, Intel CPUs are\\\\ncurrently the winners. It is not uncommon to get only half the performance on\\\\nan AMD Opteron CPU compared to similar Nehalem EP/Westmere EP/Sandy Bridge\\\\nIntel CPUs with Redis. When client and server run on the same box, the CPU is\\\\nthe limiting factor with redis-benchmark.\\\\n+ Speed of RAM and memory bandwidth seem less critical for global performance\\\\nespecially for small objects. For large objects (>10 KB), it may become\\\\nnoticeable though. Usually, it is not really cost-effective to buy expensive\\\\nfast memory modules to optimize Redis.\\\\n+ Redis runs slower on a VM compared to running without virtualization using\\\\nthe same hardware. If you have the chance to run Redis on a physical machine\\\\nthis is preferred. However this does not mean that Redis is slow in\\\\nvirtualized environments, the delivered performances are still very good\\\\nand most of the serious performance issues you may incur in virtualized\\\\nenvironments are due to over-provisioning, non-local disks with high latency,\\\\nor old hypervisor software that have slow `fork` syscall implementation.\\\\n+ When the server and client benchmark programs run on the same box, both\\\\nthe TCP/IP loopback and unix domain sockets can be used. Depending on the\\\\nplatform, unix domain sockets can achieve around 50% more throughput than\\\\nthe TCP/IP loopback (on Linux for instance). The default behavior of\\\\nredis-benchmark is to use the TCP/IP loopback.\\\\n+ The performance benefit of unix domain sockets compared to TCP/IP loopback\\\\ntends to decrease when pipelining is heavily used (i.e. long pipelines).\\\\n+ When an ethernet network is used to access Redis, aggregating commands using\\\\npipelining is especially efficient when the size of the data is kept under\\\\nthe ethernet packet size (about 1500 bytes). Actually, processing 10 bytes,\\\\n100 bytes, or 1000 bytes queries almost result in the same throughput.\\\\nSee the graph below.\\\\n\\\\n![Data size impact](https://github.com/dspezia/redis-doc/raw/client_command/topics/Data_size.png)\\\\n\\\\n+ On multi CPU sockets servers, Redis performance becomes dependent on the\\\\nNUMA configuration and process location. The most visible effect is that\\\\nredis-benchmark results seem non-deterministic because client and server\\\\nprocesses are distributed randomly on the cores. To get deterministic results,\\\\nit is required to use process placement tools (on Linux: taskset or numactl).\\\\nThe most efficient combination is always to put the client and server on two\\\\ndifferent cores of the same CPU to benefit from the L3 cache.\\\\nHere are some results of 4 KB SET benchmark for 3 server CPUs (AMD Istanbul,\\\\nIntel Nehalem EX, and Intel Westmere) with different relative placements.\\\\nPlease note this benchmark is not meant to compare CPU models between themselves\\\\n(CPUs exact model and frequency are therefore not disclosed).\\\\n\\\\n![NUMA chart](https://github.com/dspezia/redis-doc/raw/6374a07f93e867353e5e946c1e39a573dfc83f6c/topics/NUMA_chart.gif)\\\\n\\\\n+ With high-end configurations, the number of client connections is also an\\\\nimportant factor. Being based on epoll/kqueue, the Redis event loop is quite\\\\nscalable. Redis has already been benchmarked at more than 60000 connections,\\\\nand was still able to sustain 50000 q/s in these conditions. As a rule of thumb,\\\\nan instance with 30000 connections can only process half the throughput\\\\nachievable with 100 connections. Here is an example showing the throughput of\\\\na Redis instance per number of connections:\\\\n\\\\n![connections chart](https://github.com/dspezia/redis-doc/raw/system_info/topics/Connections_chart.png)\\\\n\\\\n+ With high-end configurations, it is possible to achieve higher throughput by\\\\ntuning the NIC(s) configuration and associated interruptions. Best throughput\\\\nis achieved by setting an affinity between Rx/Tx NIC queues and CPU cores,\\\\nand activating RPS (Receive Packet Steering) support. More information in this\\\\n[thread](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/redis-db/gUhc19gnYgc/BruTPCOroiMJ).\\\\nJumbo frames may also provide a performance boost when large objects are used.\\\\n+ Depending on the platform, Redis can be compiled against different memory\\\\nallocators (libc malloc, jemalloc, tcmalloc), which may have different behaviors\\\\nin term of raw speed, internal and external fragmentation.\\\\nIf you did not compile Redis yourself, you can use the INFO command to check\\\\nthe `mem_allocator` field. Please note most benchmarks do not run long enough to\\\\ngenerate significant external fragmentation (contrary to production Redis\\\\ninstances).\\\\n\\\\nOther things to consider\\\\n------------------------\\\\n\\\\nOne important goal of any benchmark is to get reproducible results, so they\\\\ncan be compared to the results of other tests.\\\\n\\\\n+ A good practice is to try to run tests on isolated hardware as much as possible.\\\\nIf it is not possible, then the system must be monitored to check the benchmark\\\\nis not impacted by some external activity.\\\\n+ Some configurations (desktops and laptops for sure, some servers as well)\\\\nhave a variable CPU core frequency mechanism. The policy controlling this\\\\nmechanism can be set at the OS level. Some CPU models are more aggressive than\\\\nothers at adapting the frequency of the CPU cores to the workload. To get\\\\nreproducible results, it is better to set the highest possible fixed frequency\\\\nfor all the CPU cores involved in the benchmark.\\\\n+ An important point is to size the system accordingly to the benchmark.\\\\nThe system must have enough RAM and must not swap. On Linux, do not forget\\\\nto set the `overcommit_memory` parameter correctly. Please note 32 and 64 bit\\\\nRedis instances do not have the same memory footprint.\\\\n+ If you plan to use RDB or AOF for your benchmark, please check there is no other\\\\nI/O activity in the system. Avoid putting RDB or AOF files on NAS or NFS shares,\\\\nor on any other devices impacting your network bandwidth and/or latency\\\\n(for instance, EBS on Amazon EC2).\\\\n+ Set Redis logging level (loglevel parameter) to warning or notice. Avoid putting\\\\nthe generated log file on a remote filesystem.\\\\n+ Avoid using monitoring tools which can alter the result of the benchmark. For\\\\ninstance using INFO at regular interval to gather statistics is probably fine,\\\\nbut MONITOR will impact the measured performance significantly.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 3.5715,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"a6d3756f\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"a6d3756f-001\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/reference/arm.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"ARM support\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Performance\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"Performance testing of Redis was performed on the Raspberry Pi 3 and Pi 1 model B. The difference between the two Pis in terms of delivered performance is quite big. The benchmarks were performed via the\\\\nloopback interface, since most use cases will probably use Redis from within\\\\nthe device and not via the network. The following numbers were obtained using\\\\nRedis 4.0.\\\\n\\\\nRaspberry Pi 3:\\\\n\\\\n* Test 1 : 5 millions writes with 1 million keys (even distribution among keys).  No persistence, no pipelining. 28,000 ops/sec.\\\\n* Test 2: Like test 1 but with pipelining using groups of 8 operations: 80,000 ops/sec.\\\\n* Test 3: Like test 1 but with AOF enabled, fsync 1 sec: 23,000 ops/sec\\\\n* Test 4: Like test 3, but with an AOF rewrite in progress: 21,000 ops/sec\\\\n\\\\nRaspberry Pi 1 model B:\\\\n\\\\n* Test 1 : 5 millions writes with 1 million keys (even distribution among keys).  No persistence, no pipelining.  2,200 ops/sec.\\\\n* Test 2: Like test 1 but with pipelining using groups of 8 operations: 8,500 ops/sec.\\\\n* Test 3: Like test 1 but with AOF enabled, fsync 1 sec: 1,820 ops/sec\\\\n* Test 4: Like test 3, but with an AOF rewrite in progress: 1,000 ops/sec\\\\n\\\\nThe benchmarks above are referring to simple [`SET`](/commands/set)/[`GET`](/commands/get) operations. The performance is similar for all the Redis fast operations (not running in linear time). However sorted sets may show slightly slower numbers.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.4557,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"b2f10184\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"b2f10184-000\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/release-notes/redisgraph/redisgraph-2.2-release-notes.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Redisgraph 2.2 Release Notes\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"v2.2.14 (16 February 2021)\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"RedisGraph v2.2.16 requires:\\\\n\\\\n- Minimum Redis compatibility version (database): 5.0.7\\\\n- Minimum Redis Enterprise Software version (cluster): 6.0.8\\\\n\\\\nThis is a maintenance release for version 2.2.\\\\n\\\\nUpdate urgency: Medium\\\\n\\\\nHeadlines:\\\\n\\\\n- This release improves overall stability and provides fixes for issues found after the previous release.\\\\n\\\\nDetails:\\\\n\\\\n- Enhancements:\\\\n\\\\n    - #[1610](https://github.com/RedisGraph/RedisGraph/pull/1610) Add module-level configuration for query timeouts\\\\n    - #[1572](https://github.com/RedisGraph/RedisGraph/pull/1572) Remove query size limitation from parser\\\\n    - #[1590](https://github.com/RedisGraph/RedisGraph/pull/1590) Improve reporting of runtime errors\\\\n    - #[1596](https://github.com/RedisGraph/RedisGraph/pull/1596) Run bulk loader commands on a non-blocking thread\\\\n\\\\n- Performance Improvements:\\\\n\\\\n    - #[1569](https://github.com/RedisGraph/RedisGraph/pull/1569) Avoid network overhead of emitting arrays with postponed length values\\\\n\\\\n- Bugfixes:\\\\n\\\\n    - #[1573](https://github.com/RedisGraph/RedisGraph/pull/1573) Lock graph on building/deleting full-text indexes, fixing a bug in full-text index replication\\\\n    - #[1618](https://github.com/RedisGraph/RedisGraph/pull/1618) Fix error in traversals of 3 or more possible relationship types\\\\n\\\\n- Infrastructure:\\\\n\\\\n    - #[1557](https://github.com/RedisGraph/RedisGraph/pull/1557) Add automated performance benchmarks and regression testing\\\\n    - #[1587](https://github.com/RedisGraph/RedisGraph/pull/1587), #[1598](https://github.com/RedisGraph/RedisGraph/pull/1598) Create build artifacts for multiple environments\\\\n\\\\nThis is a maintenance release for version 2.2.\\\\n\\\\nUpdate urgency: Medium\\\\n\\\\nHeadlines:\\\\n\\\\n- This release improves overall stability and provides fixes for issues found after the previous release.\\\\n\\\\nDetails:\\\\n\\\\n- Performance improvements:\\\\n\\\\n    - #[1565](https://github.com/RedisGraph/RedisGraph/pull/1565) Reserve a single thread for performing all write queries.\\\\n    - #[1548](https://github.com/RedisGraph/RedisGraph/pull/1548), #[1553](https://github.com/RedisGraph/RedisGraph/pull/1553), #[1554](https://github.com/RedisGraph/RedisGraph/pull/1554) only perform SET property updates when property value is changed.\\\\n    - #[1543](https://github.com/RedisGraph/RedisGraph/pull/1543) Enable O3 compiler optimizations on libcypher-parser.\\\\n\\\\n- Bugfixes:\\\\n\\\\n    - #[1556](https://github.com/RedisGraph/RedisGraph/pull/1556) Avoid premature freeing of Records in create and update contexts.\\\\n    - #[1541](https://github.com/RedisGraph/RedisGraph/pull/1541) Fix excessive memory consumption in OpApply.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 1.3574,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"e1c7f6a2\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"e1c7f6a2-008\\",\\n    \\"path\\": \\"/home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/operate/oss_and_stack/stack-with-enterprise/search/query-performance-factor.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"Query Performance Factor\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"Monitoring Redis Query Engine\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"To monitor a database with a query performance factor configured:\\\\n\\\\n1. Integrate your Redis Software deployment with Prometheus. See [Prometheus and Grafana with Redis Software]() for instructions.\\\\n\\\\n1. Monitor the `redis_process_cpu_usage_percent` shard metric.\\\\n\\\\n    The following Prometheus UI screenshot shows `redis_process_cpu_usage_percent` spikes for a database with two shards:\\\\n\\\\n    - 1st 100% spike: [`memtier_benchmark`](https://github.com/RedisLabs/memtier_benchmark) search test at the default (no additional CPUs for search).\\\\n\\\\n    - 2nd 100% spike: reconfiguration and shard restart for a 4x query performance factor.\\\\n\\\\n    - 3rd 600% spike: `memtier_benchmark` search test with threading at a 4x query performance factor (6 CPUs per shard).\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

[TextBlock(text="Based on the knowledge base, here's how to benchmark Redis performance:

## Primary Tool: redis-benchmark

Redis includes a built-in utility called `redis-benchmark` that simulates running commands by N clients sending M total queries (similar to Apache's `ab` utility).

### Basic Usage

```bash
redis-benchmark -q -n 100000
```

### Key Options

- `-h <hostname>` - Server hostname (default 127.0.0.1)
- `-p <port>` - Server port (default 6379)
- `-c <clients>` - Number of parallel connections (default 50)
- `-n <requests>` - Total number of requests (default 100000)
- `-d <size>` - Data size of SET/GET value in bytes (default 3)
- `-t <tests>` - Only run specific tests (comma-separated)
- `-P <numreq>` - Pipeline requests (default 1, no pipeline)
- `-q` - Quiet mode, just show query/sec values
- `--threads <num>` - Enable multi-thread mode

### Example: Test Specific Commands

```bash
redis-benchmark -t set,lpush -n 100000 -q
```

### Example: Using Pipelining (Higher Throughput)

```bash
redis-benchmark -n 1000000 -t set,get -P 16 -q
```

Pipelining can dramatically improve performance (e.g., from ~72K to 1.5M+ requests/sec for SET operations).

## Alternative Third-Party Tools

1. **memtier_benchmark** (Redis Labs) - NoSQL Redis and Memcache traffic generation and benchmarking tool
   - GitHub: https://github.com/redislabs/memtier_benchmark

2. **rpc-perf** (Twitter) - Benchmarking tool for RPC services supporting Redis and Memcache
   - GitHub: https://github.com/twitter/rpc-perf

3. **YCSB** (Yahoo) - Benchmarking framework with clients for many databases including Redis
   - GitHub: https://github.com/brianfrankcooper/YCSB

messages.result:
Based on the knowledge base, here's how to benchmark Redis performance:

## Primary Tool: redis-benchmark

Redis includes a built-in utility called `redis-benchmark` that simulates running commands by N clients sending M total queries (similar to Apache's `ab` utility).

### Basic Usage

```bash
redis-benchmark -q -n 100000
```

### Key Options

- `-h <hostname>` - Server hostname (default 127.0.0.1)
- `-p <port>` - Server port (default 6379)
- `-c <clients>` - Number of parallel connections (default 50)
- `-n <requests>` - Total number of requests (default 100000)
- `-d <size>` - Data size of SET/GET value in bytes (default 3)
- `-t <tests>` - Only run specific tests (comma-separated)
- `-P <numreq>` - Pipeline requests (default 1, no pipeline)
- `-q` - Quiet mode, just show query/sec values
- `--threads <num>` - Enable multi-thread mode

### Example: Test Specific Commands

```bash
redis-benchmark -t set,lpush -n 100000 -q
```

### Example: Using Pipelining (Higher Throughput)

```bash
redis-benchmark -n 1000000 -t set,get -P 16 -q
```

Pipelining can dramatically improve performance (e.g., from ~72K to 1.5M+ requests/sec for SET operations).

## Alternative Third-Party Tools

1. **memtier_benchmark** (Redis Labs) - NoSQL Redis and Memcache traffic generation and benchmarking tool
   - GitHub: https://github.com/redislabs/memtier_benchmark

2. **rpc-perf** (Twitter) - Benchmarking tool for RPC services supporting Redis and Memcache
   - GitHub: https://github.com/twitter/rpc-perf

3. **YCSB** (Yahoo) - Benchmarking framework with clients for many databases including Redis
   - GitHub: https://github.com/brianfrankcooper/YCSB

query: Redis vector sets 怎么做 filtered search？能结合标签过滤吗？
answer:
根据检索结果，Redis vector sets 确实支持 filtered search，并且可以结合标签（属性）过滤。以下是详细说明：

## Filtered Search 功能

Redis vector sets 支持在向量相似度搜索时结合标量过滤，通过 JSON 属性实现类似"标签过滤"的功能。

### 基本用法

**1. 添加向量时设置属性（标签）**

```bash
# 使用 SETATTR 参数添加属性
VADD vset VALUES 3 1 1 1 a SETATTR '{"year": 1950}'
```

**2. 后续更新属性**

```bash
# 使用 VSETATTR 命令
VSETATTR vset a '{"year": 1960}'
```

**3. 查询属性**

```bash
# 使用 VGETATTR 命令
VGETATTR vset a
```

**4. 执行 Filtered Search**

```bash
# 在 VSIM 查询中使用 FILTER 选项
VSIM vset VALUES 3 0 0 0 FILTER '.year > 1950'
```

这会返回同时满足向量相似度和过滤条件的元素。

### 过滤表达式语法

支持类 JavaScript 的表达式语法：

- **算术运算**: `+`, `-`, `*`, `/`, `%`, `**`
- **比较运算**: `==`, `!=`, `>`, `<`, `>=`, `<=`
- **逻辑运算**: `and`, `or`, `not`（或 `&&`, `||`, `!`）
- **包含运算**: `in`
- **分组**: 括号 `()`

使用点号访问属性字段，例如 `.year`, `.rating`。

⚠️ **注意**: 仅支持顶层字段（如 `.genre`），不支持嵌套字段（如 `.movie.genre`）。

### 实际示例

```bash
# 按年份范围过滤
VSIM movies VALUES 3 0.5 0.8 0.2 FILTER '.year >= 1980 and .year < 1990'

# 按类型和评分过滤
VSIM movies VALUES 3 0.5 0.8 0.2 FILTER '.genre == "action" and .rating > 8.0'

# 使用 IN 操作符（数组）
VSIM movies VALUES 3 0.5 0.8 0.2 FILTER '.director in ["Spielberg", "Nolan"]'

# 复杂表达式
VSIM movies VALUES 3 0.5 0.8 0.2 FILTER '(.year - 2000) ** 2 < 100 and .rating / 2 > 4'
```

### 性能调优：FILTER-EF 参数

`FILTER-EF` 控制引擎检查多少候选节点以找到足够的过滤结果（默认值为 `COUNT * 100`）：

```bash
VSIM vset VALUES 3 0 0 0 COUNT 10 FILTER '.year > 2000' FILTER-EF 500
```

- 对于稀有过滤条件，使用更高的值
- 使用 `FILTER-EF 0` 扫描尽可能多的节点以满足请求
- 引擎会在找到足够高质量结果时提前停止

### 支持的数据类型

- 数字（Numbers）
- 字符串（Strings）
- 布尔值（转换为 1 或 0）
- 数组（用于 `in` 操作）

如果字段缺失或无效，该元素会被跳过，不会报错。

### 最佳实践

- 缺失的属性会被视为不匹配
- 使用 `FILTER-EF` 调优召回率与性能
- 组合多个属性实现细粒度过滤

You can associate JSON attributes with elements in a vector set, and then filter results using those attributes during [`VSIM`]() queries.\\\\n\\\\nThis allows queries such as:\\\\n\\\\n```bash\\\\nVSIM movies VALUES 3 0.5 0.8 0.2 FILTER \'.year >= 1980 and .rating > 7\'\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nYou can associate attributes when adding a new vector using the `SETATTR` argument:\\\\n\\\\n```bash\\\\nVADD vset VALUES 3 1 1 1 a SETATTR \'{\\\\\\"year\\\\\\": 1950}\'\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nOr update them later with the [`VSETATTR`]() command:\\\\n\\\\n```bash\\\\nVSETATTR vset a \'{\\\\\\"year\\\\\\": 1960}\'\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nYou can retrieve attributes with the [`VGETATTR`]() command:\\\\n\\\\n```bash\\\\nVGETATTR vset a\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nTo filter by attributes, pass the `FILTER` option to the [`VSIM`]() command:\\\\n\\\\n```bash\\\\nVSIM vset VALUES 3 0 0 0 FILTER \'.year > 1950\'\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nThis returns only elements that match both the vector similarity and the filter expression.\\\\n\\\\nExpressions support familiar JavaScript-like syntax:\\\\n\\\\n- Arithmetic: `+`, `-`, `*`, `/`, `%`, `**`\\\\n- Comparison: `==`, `!=`, `>`, `<`, `>=`, `<=`\\\\n- Logical: `and`, `or`, `not` (or `&&`, `||`, `!`)\\\\n- Containment: `in`\\\\n- Grouping: Parentheses `()`\\\\n\\\\nUse dot notation to access attribute fields, for example, `.year`, `.rating`.\\\\n\\\\n> Only top-level fields are supported (for example, `.genre`, but not `.movie.genre`).\\\\n\\\\n- Numbers\\\\n- Strings\\\\n- Booleans (converted to 1 or 0)\\\\n- Arrays (for `in`)\\\\n\\\\nIf a field is missing or invalid, the element is skipped without error.\\\\n\\\\nThe `FILTER-EF` option controls how many candidate nodes the engine inspects to find enough filtered results. That makes debugging trickier than with exact match queries. This section helps you understand issues with recall, filtering, and graph structure.\\\\n\\\\nIf [`VSIM`]() doesn\'t return expected items:\\\\n\\\\n- Increase the `EF` parameter:\\\\n\\\\n  ```bash\\\\n  VSIM myset VALUES 3 ... COUNT 10 EF 1000\\\\n  ```\\\\n\\\\n- Check quantization mode. Binary quantization (`BIN`) trades accuracy for speed.\\\\n- Use `TRUTH` to compare results against a linear scan:\\\\n\\\\n  ```bash\\\\n  VSIM myset VALUES 3 ... COUNT 10 TRUTH\\\\n  ```\\\\n\\\\n  This gives you the most accurate results for validation, but it\'s slow.\\\\n\\\\nFilters silently exclude items if:\\\\n\\\\n- A field is missing from the element’s attributes\\\\n- The JSON is invalid\\\\n- A type doesn’t match the expression (for example, `.rating > 8` when `.rating` is a string)\\\\n\\\\nTry retrieving the attributes with [`VGETATTR`]():\\\\n\\\\n```bash\\\\nVGETATTR myset myelement\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nDouble-check field names, JSON validity, and value types.\\\\n\\\\nMemory issues may arise from:\\\\n\\\\n- Large vectors (use `REDUCE` to project down)\\\\n- High `M` values inflating link graphs\\\\n- Large or deeply nested JSON attributes\\\\n- Storing raw `FP32` vectors (`NOQUANT`)\\\\n\\\\nUse default `Q8` quantization and compact attributes to save space.\\\\n\\\\nUse [`VLINKS`]() to examine a node’s connections:\\\\n\\\\n```bash\\\\nVLINKS myset myelement WITHSCORES\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n- Helps you verify whether isolated or weakly connected nodes exist.\\\\n- Useful for explaining poor recall.\\\\n\\\\nLarge sets deleted using the `DEL` command can briefly spike latency as Redis reclaims memory and rebuilds HNSW linkages.\\\\n\\\\n- `VADD` with `REDUCE` does not replicate the random projection matrix.\\\\n- Replicas will produce different projected vectors for the same inputs.\\\\n\\\\nThis doesn\'t affect similarity searches but does affect [`VEMB`]() output.\\\\n\\\\n| Symptom                          | Try this                                                  |\\\\n|----------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------|\\\\n| Poor recall                      | Use higher `EF`, check quantization, use `TRUTH` `BFLOAT16` and `FLOAT16` vector data types, reducing memory consumed by vectors while preserving accuracy. This update also includes highly-requested support for indexing empty and missing values and enhances the developer experience for queries with exact matching capabilities. Developers can now match `TAG` fields without needing to escape special characters, making the onboarding process and use of the query syntax easier. [#4676](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/4676), [#4433](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/4433) - Enhancing query parser to avoid unnecessary escaping (MOD-5756)\\\\n  - [#4527](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/4527) - Enhancing exact matching queries for `NUMERIC` using single value `FT.SEARCH idx @numeric:[3456]` (MOD-6623)\\\\n  - [#4802](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/4802) - Enabling support for single operators in `NUMERIC` queries such as equivalence `==`, difference `!=`, greater than `>` and `>=` and less than `<` and `<=` as in `FT.SEARCH idx \'@numeric==3456\'` (MOD-6749)\\\\n\\\\n- Adding new keywords to support indexing empty values using `INDEXEMPTY` and missing values using `INDEXMISSING` per field in the `SCHEMA` while defining the [index](https://redis.io/docs/latest/commands/ft.create/) with `FT.CREATE`\\\\n  - [#4663](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/4663), [#4721](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/4721) - Indexing empty strings values `\\\\\\"\\\\\\"` for `TAG` and `TEXT` fields (MOD-6540, MOD-7200)\\\\n  - [#4721](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/4721) - Updating the query parser to support empty value queries for `TEXT` as `FT.SEARCH idx \'@text_field:\\\\\\"\\\\\\"\'`or `FT.SEARCH idx \'\\\\\\"\\\\\\"\'` and for `TAG` as in `FT.SEARCH idx \'@tag_field:{\\\\\\"\\\\\\"}\'` (MOD-7200)\\\\n  - [#4720](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/4720), [#4635](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/4635) - Indexing missing values for all field types introducing the query syntax function `ismissing(@field)` enabling query for missing fields as in `FT.SEARCH idx \'ismissing(@text)\'` (MOD-6532)\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n- Enabling new vector data types reducing memory consumed by vectors with the new `BFLOAT16` and `FLOAT16`\\\\n  - [#4674](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/4674) - Adding support `BFLOAT16` and `FLOAT16` in the [vector index definition](https://redis.io/docs/latest/develop/ai/search-and-query/vectors/#creation-attributes-per-algorithm) (MOD-6765, MOD-6776)\\\\n\\\\n- Exposing the full-text score values during the aggregation pipeline using `ADDSCORE`. When calling the scores you can use `@__score` in the pipeline as in `FT.AGGREGATE idx \'hello\' ADDSCORES SORTBY 2 @__score DESC`\\\\n  - [#4859](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/4859) - Expose scores to `FT.AGGREGATE` pipeline (MOD-7190)\\\\n\\\\n- [#4227](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/4227) - Adding support for new operators `INTERSECT` and `DISJOINT` when querying for `GEOSHAPE` [polygons](https://redis.io/docs/latest/develop/ai/search-and-query/query/geo-spatial/) (MOD-6178)\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nBug fixes (since 2.10.4):\\\\n- [#4854](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/4854) - Avoid expansion on stemming from numeric values (MOD-7025)\\\\n\\\\nImprovements (since 2.10.4):\\\\n- [#4865](https://github.com/RediSearch/RediSearch/pull/4865) - Add coverage for cleaning garbage entries when indexing missing fields (MOD-7415)\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n- The version inside Redis will be 2.10.5 in semantic versioning. Since the version of a module in Redis is numeric, we could not add a Release Candidate flag.\\\\n- Minimal Redis version: 7.4\\\\n- If indexing and querying RedisJSON data structures, this version is best combined with RedisJSON 2.8 (v2.8.2 onwards)\\\\n- If one or more fields of a hash key expire after a query begins (using FT.SEARCH or FT.AGGREGATE), Redis does not account for these lazily expired fields. This enables the frequently asked feature of affix search and includes optimized wildcard query support :\\\\n   - `?` matches any single character\\\\n   - `*` matches zero or more characters\\\\n   - use `’` and `\\\\\\\\` for escaping, other special characters are ignored\\\\n* Multi-value indexing and querying of attributes for any attribute type ([Text](https://redis.io/docs/stack/search/indexing_json/#index-json-arrays-as-text), [Tag](https://redis.io/docs/stack/search/indexing_json/#index-json-arrays-as-tag), [Numeric](https://redis.io/docs/stack/search/indexing_json/#index-json-arrays-as-numeric), [Geo](https://redis.io/docs/stack/search/indexing_json/#index-json-arrays-as-geo) and [Vector](https://redis.io/docs/stack/search/indexing_json/#index-json-arrays-as-vector)) defined by a [JSONPath](https://redis.io/docs/stack/json/path/) leading to an array:\\\\n  - Multi-value text search - perform full-text search on [array of string or on a JSONPath](https://redis.io/docs/stack/search/indexing_json/#index-json-arrays-as-tag) leading to multiple strings\\\\n  - Return JSON rather than scalars from multi-value attributes. Whenever a failure occurs, the query effect is rolled-back from an undo-log.\\\\n \\\\n**RedisTimeSeries** introduces the following new features:\\\\n* Introduction of a new aggregator: `twa` (time-weighted average)\\\\n* Introduction of a new optional `EMPTY` flag to `TS.RANGE`, `TS.REVRANGE`, `TS.MRANGE`, and `TS.MREVRANGE` to retrieve aggregations for empty buckets as well.\\\\n* Gap-filling: Using `EMPTY` when the aggregator is `twa` allows estimating the average of a continuous signal even for empty buckets based on linear interpolation of previous and next samples. RAG enhances LLMs by integrating them with external, domain-specific data stored in a Redis [vector database]().\\\\n\\\\nRAG involves three main steps:\\\\n\\\\n- **Retrieve**: Fetch relevant information from Redis using vector search and filters based on the user query.\\\\n- **Augment**: Create a prompt for the LLM, including the user query, relevant context, and additional instructions.\\\\n- **Generate**: Return the response generated by the LLM to the user.\\\\n\\\\nRAG enables LLMs to use real-time information, improving the accuracy and relevance of generated content.\\\\nRedis is ideal for RAG due to its speed, versatility, and familiarity.\\\\n\\\\nRedis provides a robust platform for managing real-time data. It supports the storage and retrieval of vectors, essential for handling large-scale, unstructured data and performing similarity searches. Key features and components of Redis that make it suitable for RAG include:\\\\n\\\\n1. **Vector database**: Stores and indexes vector embeddings that semantically represent unstructured data.\\\\n1. **Semantic cache**: Caches frequently asked questions (FAQs) in a RAG pipeline. Using vector search, Redis retrieves similar previously answered questions, reducing LLM inference costs and latency.\\\\n1. **LLM session manager**: Stores conversation history between an LLM and a user. Redis fetches recent and relevant portions of the chat history to provide context, improving the quality and accuracy of responses.\\\\n1. **High performance and scalability**: Known for its [low latency and high throughput](https://redis.io/blog/benchmarking-results-for-vector-databases/), Redis is ideal for RAG systems and AI agents requiring rapid data retrieval and generation.\\"\\n  }\\n]"}', is_error=None)]

[TextBlock(text='根据检索结果，Redis vector sets 确实支持 filtered search，并且可以结合标签（属性）过滤。以下是详细说明：

## Filtered Search 功能

Redis vector sets 支持在向量相似度搜索时结合标量过滤，通过 JSON 属性实现类似"标签过滤"的功能。

### 基本用法

**1. 添加向量时设置属性（标签）**

```bash
# 使用 SETATTR 参数添加属性
VADD vset VALUES 3 1 1 1 a SETATTR '{"year": 1950}'
```

**2. 后续更新属性**

```bash
# 使用 VSETATTR 命令
VSETATTR vset a '{"year": 1960}'
```

**3. 查询属性**

```bash
# 使用 VGETATTR 命令
VGETATTR vset a
```

**4. 执行 Filtered Search**

```bash
# 在 VSIM 查询中使用 FILTER 选项
VSIM vset VALUES 3 0 0 0 FILTER '.year > 1950'
```

这会返回同时满足向量相似度和过滤条件的元素。

### 过滤表达式语法

支持类 JavaScript 的表达式语法：

- **算术运算**: `+`, `-`, `*`, `/`, `%`, `**`
- **比较运算**: `==`, `!=`, `>`, `<`, `>=`, `<=`
- **逻辑运算**: `and`, `or`, `not`（或 `&&`, `||`, `!`）
- **包含运算**: `in`
- **分组**: 括号 `()`

使用点号访问属性字段，例如 `.year`, `.rating`。

⚠️ **注意**: 仅支持顶层字段（如 `.genre`），不支持嵌套字段（如 `.movie.genre`）。

### 实际示例

```bash
# 按年份范围过滤
VSIM movies VALUES 3 0.5 0.8 0.2 FILTER '.year >= 1980 and .year < 1990'

# 按类型和评分过滤
VSIM movies VALUES 3 0.5 0.8 0.2 FILTER '.genre == "action" and .rating > 8.0'

# 使用 IN 操作符（数组）
VSIM movies VALUES 3 0.5 0.8 0.2 FILTER '.director in ["Spielberg", "Nolan"]'

# 复杂表达式
VSIM movies VALUES 3 0.5 0.8 0.2 FILTER '(.year - 2000) ** 2 < 100 and .rating / 2 > 4'
```

### 性能调优：FILTER-EF 参数

`FILTER-EF` 控制引擎检查多少候选节点以找到足够的过滤结果（默认值为 `COUNT * 100`）：

```bash
VSIM vset VALUES 3 0 0 0 COUNT 10 FILTER '.year > 2000' FILTER-EF 500
```

- 对于稀有过滤条件，使用更高的值
- 使用 `FILTER-EF 0` 扫描尽可能多的节点以满足请求
- 引擎会在找到足够高质量结果时提前停止

### 支持的数据类型

- 数字（Numbers）
- 字符串（Strings）
- 布尔值（转换为 1 或 0）
- 数组（用于 `in` 操作）

如果字段缺失或无效，该元素会被跳过，不会报错。

### 最佳实践

- 缺失的属性会被视为不匹配
- 使用 `FILTER-EF` 调优召回率与性能
- 组合多个属性实现细粒度过滤

messages.result:
根据检索结果，Redis vector sets 确实支持 filtered search，并且可以结合标签（属性）过滤。以下是详细说明：

## Filtered Search 功能

Redis vector sets 支持在向量相似度搜索时结合标量过滤，通过 JSON 属性实现类似"标签过滤"的功能。

### 基本用法

**1. 添加向量时设置属性（标签）**

```bash
# 使用 SETATTR 参数添加属性
VADD vset VALUES 3 1 1 1 a SETATTR '{"year": 1950}'
```

**2. 后续更新属性**

```bash
# 使用 VSETATTR 命令
VSETATTR vset a '{"year": 1960}'
```

**3. 查询属性**

```bash
# 使用 VGETATTR 命令
VGETATTR vset a
```

**4. 执行 Filtered Search**

```bash
# 在 VSIM 查询中使用 FILTER 选项
VSIM vset VALUES 3 0 0 0 FILTER '.year > 1950'
```

这会返回同时满足向量相似度和过滤条件的元素。

### 过滤表达式语法

支持类 JavaScript 的表达式语法：

- **算术运算**: `+`, `-`, `*`, `/`, `%`, `**`
- **比较运算**: `==`, `!=`, `>`, `<`, `>=`, `<=`
- **逻辑运算**: `and`, `or`, `not`（或 `&&`, `||`, `!`）
- **包含运算**: `in`
- **分组**: 括号 `()`

使用点号访问属性字段，例如 `.year`, `.rating`。

⚠️ **注意**: 仅支持顶层字段（如 `.genre`），不支持嵌套字段（如 `.movie.genre`）。

### 实际示例

```bash
# 按年份范围过滤
VSIM movies VALUES 3 0.5 0.8 0.2 FILTER '.year >= 1980 and .year < 1990'

# 按类型和评分过滤
VSIM movies VALUES 3 0.5 0.8 0.2 FILTER '.genre == "action" and .rating > 8.0'

# 使用 IN 操作符（数组）
VSIM movies VALUES 3 0.5 0.8 0.2 FILTER '.director in ["Spielberg", "Nolan"]'

# 复杂表达式
VSIM movies VALUES 3 0.5 0.8 0.2 FILTER '(.year - 2000) ** 2 < 100 and .rating / 2 > 4'
```

### 性能调优：FILTER-EF 参数

`FILTER-EF` 控制引擎检查多少候选节点以找到足够的过滤结果（默认值为 `COUNT * 100`）：

```bash
VSIM vset VALUES 3 0 0 0 COUNT 10 FILTER '.year > 2000' FILTER-EF 500
```

- 对于稀有过滤条件，使用更高的值
- 使用 `FILTER-EF 0` 扫描尽可能多的节点以满足请求
- 引擎会在找到足够高质量结果时提前停止

### 支持的数据类型

- 数字（Numbers）
- 字符串（Strings）
- 布尔值（转换为 1 或 0）
- 数组（用于 `in` 操作）

如果字段缺失或无效，该元素会被跳过，不会报错。

### 最佳实践

- 缺失的属性会被视为不匹配
- 使用 `FILTER-EF` 调优召回率与性能
- 组合多个属性实现细粒度过滤

query: How to install Redis Stack on Ubuntu with apt?
answer:
To install Redis Stack on Ubuntu with apt, follow these steps:

**1. Add the Redis repository:**

```bash
sudo apt-get install lsb-release curl gpg
curl -fsSL https://packages.redis.io/gpg | sudo gpg --dearmor -o /usr/share/keyrings/redis-archive-keyring.gpg
sudo chmod 644 /usr/share/keyrings/redis-archive-keyring.gpg
echo "deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/redis-archive-keyring.gpg] https://packages.redis.io/deb $(lsb_release -cs) main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/redis.list
```

**2. Update and install Redis Stack:**

```bash
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install redis-stack-server
```

**3. Enable and start the service:**

Redis won't start automatically after installation. To enable it at boot and start it now:

```bash
sudo systemctl enable redis-stack-server
sudo systemctl start redis-stack-server
```

**4. Verify the installation:**

```bash
redis-cli
127.0.0.1:6379> ping
PONG
```

query: How to build a local RAG agent with Llama?
answer:
Based on the knowledge base, here's how to build a local RAG agent with Llama:

## Overview

You can build a fully local RAG system using **Llama 3.2** with **Ollama**, **Qdrant** for vector storage, and **Agno v2.0** framework. This setup requires no external API dependencies.

## Step-by-Step Setup

### 1. Prerequisites
```bash
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/local_rag_agent
```

### 2. Install Dependencies
```bash
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

### 3. Set Up Vector Database
```bash
# Pull and run Qdrant locally
docker pull qdrant/qdrant
docker run -p 6333:6333 qdrant/qdrant
```

### 4. Install Ollama and Models
```bash
# Install Ollama from https://ollama.com/download

# Pull required models
ollama pull llama3.2        # For LLM
ollama pull openhermes      # For embeddings
```

### 5. Run the Application
```bash
python local_rag_agent.py
```

Access the web interface at `http://localhost:7777` through the AgentOS interface.

## Key Features

- **Fully local**: No external API calls required
- **Vector search**: Uses Qdrant for efficient similarity search
- **Document management**: Agno v2.0 Knowledge class handles document processing
- **Interactive UI**: Web-based AgentOS interface

## How It Works

1. Documents are loaded and chunked (e.g., PDF files)
2. Text is embedded using OpenHermes via Ollama
3. Embeddings are stored in Qdrant vector database
4. User queries are embedded and searched against the knowledge base
5. Llama 3.2 generates responses based on retrieved context

## Note

The knowledge base loads documents on first run. After initial setup, you can comment out the `knowledge_base.add_content()` line to avoid reloading.

[Source: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/local_rag_agent/README.md > 🦙 Local RAG Agent with Llama 3.2 > Note]

For a complete tutorial with detailed code walkthroughs, visit: https://www.theunwindai.com/p/build-a-local-rag-agent

[TextBlock(text="Based on the knowledge base, here's how to build a local RAG agent with Llama:

## Overview

You can build a fully local RAG system using **Llama 3.2** with **Ollama**, **Qdrant** for vector storage, and **Agno v2.0** framework. This setup requires no external API dependencies.

## Step-by-Step Setup

### 1. Prerequisites
```bash
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/local_rag_agent
```

### 2. Install Dependencies
```bash
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

### 3. Set Up Vector Database
```bash
# Pull and run Qdrant locally
docker pull qdrant/qdrant
docker run -p 6333:6333 qdrant/qdrant
```

### 4. Install Ollama and Models
```bash
# Install Ollama from https://ollama.com/download

# Pull required models
ollama pull llama3.2        # For LLM
ollama pull openhermes      # For embeddings
```

### 5. Run the Application
```bash
python local_rag_agent.py
```

Access the web interface at `http://localhost:7777` through the AgentOS interface.

## Key Features

- **Fully local**: No external API calls required
- **Vector search**: Uses Qdrant for efficient similarity search
- **Document management**: Agno v2.0 Knowledge class handles document processing
- **Interactive UI**: Web-based AgentOS interface

## How It Works

1. Documents are loaded and chunked (e.g., PDF files)
2. Text is embedded using OpenHermes via Ollama
3. Embeddings are stored in Qdrant vector database
4. User queries are embedded and searched against the knowledge base
5. Llama 3.2 generates responses based on retrieved context

## Note

The knowledge base loads documents on first run. After initial setup, you can comment out the `knowledge_base.add_content()` line to avoid reloading.

[Source: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/local_rag_agent/README.md > 🦙 Local RAG Agent with Llama 3.2 > Note]

For a complete tutorial with detailed code walkthroughs, visit: https://www.theunwindai.com/p/build-a-local-rag-agent")]

Based on the knowledge base, here's how to build a local RAG agent with Llama:

## Overview

You can build a fully local RAG system using **Llama 3.2** with **Ollama**, **Qdrant** for vector storage, and **Agno v2.0** framework. This setup requires no external API dependencies.

## Step-by-Step Setup

### 1. Prerequisites
```bash
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/local_rag_agent
```

### 2. Install Dependencies
```bash
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

### 3. Set Up Vector Database
```bash
# Pull and run Qdrant locally
docker pull qdrant/qdrant
docker run -p 6333:6333 qdrant/qdrant
```

### 4. Install Ollama and Models
```bash
# Install Ollama from https://ollama.com/download

# Pull required models
ollama pull llama3.2        # For LLM
ollama pull openhermes      # For embeddings
```

### 5. Run the Application
```bash
python local_rag_agent.py
```

Access the web interface at `http://localhost:7777` through the AgentOS interface.

## Key Features

- **Fully local**: No external API calls required
- **Vector search**: Uses Qdrant for efficient similarity search
- **Document management**: Agno v2.0 Knowledge class handles document processing
- **Interactive UI**: Web-based AgentOS interface

## How It Works

1. Documents are loaded and chunked (e.g., PDF files)
2. Text is embedded using OpenHermes via Ollama
3. Embeddings are stored in Qdrant vector database
4. User queries are embedded and searched against the knowledge base
5. Llama 3.2 generates responses based on retrieved context

## Note

The knowledge base loads documents on first run. After initial setup, you can comment out the `knowledge_base.add_content()` line to avoid reloading.

[Source: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/local_rag_agent/README.md > 🦙 Local RAG Agent with Llama 3.2 > Note]

For a complete tutorial with detailed code walkthroughs, visit: https://www.theunwindai.com/p/build-a-local-rag-agent

query: What is Corrective RAG and how does it improve retrieval quality?
answer:
Based on the knowledge base search results, here's what Corrective RAG is and how it improves retrieval quality:

## What is Corrective RAG?

Corrective RAG is a sophisticated multi-stage Retrieval-Augmented Generation system that implements a corrective workflow to provide more comprehensive and accurate responses. Unlike traditional RAG systems that simply retrieve and generate, Corrective RAG adds quality control and fallback mechanisms.

## How It Improves Retrieval Quality

Corrective RAG enhances retrieval quality through several key mechanisms:

1. **Document Relevance Grading**: Uses an LLM (like Claude 4.5 Sonnet) to assess whether retrieved documents are actually relevant to the query, rather than blindly using all retrieved results.

2. **Query Transformation**: When initial retrieval results are insufficient, the system optimizes and reformulates the query to improve search results.

3. **Web Search Fallback**: If local documents aren't sufficient or relevant enough, the system automatically falls back to web search (using tools like Tavily API) to find additional information.

4. **Multi-Stage Workflow**: Implements a structured pipeline using LangGraph that combines:
   - Smart document retrieval (using vector stores like Qdrant)
   - Relevance assessment
   - Query optimization when needed
   - External search when necessary

5. **Multi-Model Approach**: Combines different models for different tasks (e.g., OpenAI embeddings for retrieval, Claude for analysis and generation), optimizing each stage of the pipeline.

This corrective approach significantly reduces hallucinations and improves answer accuracy by ensuring that only relevant information is used and that the system can adapt when initial retrieval fails.

query: 怎么用 Agentic RAG 实现带推理能力的检索？
answer:
找到了关于 Agentic RAG 推理能力的详细文档。这里有一个完整的实现教程：

## 核心实现方案

**使用 Agno + Gemini 2.5 Flash + ReasoningTools** 构建带推理能力的 Agentic RAG 系统。

### 关键组件

1. **推理工具链**
   - **ReasoningTools**: 帮助 Agent 进行逐步推理
   - **Gemini 2.5 Flash**: 用于语言处理和推理生成
   - **OpenAI Embeddings**: 用于向量语义匹配
   - **LanceDB**: 向量数据库存储

2. **透明推理过程**
   - 实时展示 Agent 的思考步骤
   - 左右分栏显示：推理过程 vs 最终答案
   - 清晰可见的 RAG 处理流程

### 工作流程

```
用户查询 
  ↓
ReasoningTools 触发逐步推理
  ↓
向量搜索检索相关文档（OpenAI embeddings）
  ↓
Gemini 2.5 Flash 基于上下文生成答案
  ↓
流式输出：推理步骤 + 最终答案 + 来源引用
```

### 实现特点

- **动态知识库管理**: 支持添加 URL 动态扩展知识源
- **来源归因**: 答案带引用和出处
- **会话状态跟踪**: 防止重复加载 URL
- **实时流式输出**: 推理和内容生成同步展示

### 代码示例结构

```python
# 1. 文档加载和向量化
- 使用 Agno Knowledge 类加载 URL
- 自动分块和 embedding（OpenAI）
- 存储到 LanceDB

# 2. 推理 Agent 配置
- 集成 ReasoningTools
- 配置 Gemini 2.5 Flash
- 自定义 Agent 指令

# 3. 查询处理
- 触发推理过程
- 向量搜索知识库
- 生成带引用的答案
```

### 其他实现方案

知识库中还有其他推理 RAG 实现：

1. **Deepseek Local RAG Reasoning Agent**: 本地部署方案，支持 PDF/网页处理，带思考过程可视化
2. **Gemini Flash Thinking RAG**: 使用 Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking 模型，支持查询重写和 fallback 到 web search

## 核心实现方案

**使用 Agno + Gemini 2.5 Flash + ReasoningTools** 构建带推理能力的 Agentic RAG 系统。

### 关键组件

1. **推理工具链**
   - **ReasoningTools**: 帮助 Agent 进行逐步推理
   - **Gemini 2.5 Flash**: 用于语言处理和推理生成
   - **OpenAI Embeddings**: 用于向量语义匹配
   - **LanceDB**: 向量数据库存储

2. **透明推理过程**
   - 实时展示 Agent 的思考步骤
   - 左右分栏显示：推理过程 vs 最终答案
   - 清晰可见的 RAG 处理流程

### 工作流程

```
用户查询 
  ↓
ReasoningTools 触发逐步推理
  ↓
向量搜索检索相关文档（OpenAI embeddings）
  ↓
Gemini 2.5 Flash 基于上下文生成答案
  ↓
流式输出：推理步骤 + 最终答案 + 来源引用
```

### 实现特点

- **动态知识库管理**: 支持添加 URL 动态扩展知识源
- **来源归因**: 答案带引用和出处
- **会话状态跟踪**: 防止重复加载 URL
- **实时流式输出**: 推理和内容生成同步展示

### 代码示例结构

```python
# 1. 文档加载和向量化
- 使用 Agno Knowledge 类加载 URL
- 自动分块和 embedding（OpenAI）
- 存储到 LanceDB

# 2. 推理 Agent 配置
- 集成 ReasoningTools
- 配置 Gemini 2.5 Flash
- 自定义 Agent 指令

# 3. 查询处理
- 触发推理过程
- 向量搜索知识库
- 生成带引用的答案
```

### 其他实现方案

知识库中还有其他推理 RAG 实现：

1. **Deepseek Local RAG Reasoning Agent**: 本地部署方案，支持 PDF/网页处理，带思考过程可视化
2. **Gemini Flash Thinking RAG**: 使用 Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking 模型，支持查询重写和 fallback 到 web search

query: How to build a RAG app that can chat with PDF documents?
answer:
Based on the knowledge base search, here's how to build a RAG app that can chat with PDF documents:

## Overview

You can build a RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) app for PDF chat in as little as **30 lines of Python code** using modern frameworks. The core approach involves uploading PDFs, chunking the content, creating embeddings, storing them in a vector database, and using an LLM to generate answers based on retrieved context.

## Step-by-Step Implementation

### 1. **Basic Setup**

```bash
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd awesome-llm-apps/chat_with_X_tutorials/chat_with_pdf
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

### 2. **Core Components**

- **Document Processing**: Upload PDF → Split into chunks using RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter
- **Embeddings**: Convert chunks to vectors (using FastEmbed or OpenAI embeddings)
- **Vector Database**: Store embeddings in Qdrant for similarity search
- **LLM Integration**: Use OpenAI/Claude/local models to generate answers
- **UI**: Streamlit for interactive chat interface

### 3. **Key Features to Implement**

- PDF upload functionality
- Automatic text chunking and embedding
- Similarity search with threshold filtering
- Context-aware response generation
- Source attribution (show which PDF sections were used)

### 4. **Advanced Options**

**Hybrid Search RAG** (better accuracy):
- Combines semantic search + keyword matching
- Uses reranking (e.g., Cohere) for better context selection
- Fallback to general LLM knowledge when documents don't contain the answer

**Local RAG** (privacy-focused):
- Use local LLMs (Llama, Mistral) instead of API calls
- BGE-M3 embedder with 1024 dimensions
- Runs entirely on your machine (requires sufficient RAM/GPU)

**Voice-Enabled RAG**:
- Add text-to-speech for audio responses
- Multiple voice personality options
- Real-time audio streaming

### 5. **Database Options**

- **Qdrant**: Cloud or self-hosted vector database (recommended)
- **PostgreSQL + Pgvector**: For persistent storage with SQL capabilities
- **SQLite**: For local development/testing

### 6. **Quick Start Example**

```bash
streamlit run chat_pdf.py
```

Then:
1. Upload your PDF document
2. Wait for processing (chunking + embedding)
3. Ask questions about the content
4. Get accurate answers with source citations

## Best Practices

- Use **context window size of 4096** for most use cases
- Implement **automatic fallback to web search** when documents don't contain answers
- Add **query rewriting** for better retrieval accuracy
- Include **source attribution** to show which document sections were used
- Consider **hybrid search** (semantic + keyword) for better results than pure vector search

[TextBlock(text="Based on the knowledge base search, here's how to build a RAG app that can chat with PDF documents:

## Overview

You can build a RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) app for PDF chat in as little as **30 lines of Python code** using modern frameworks. The core approach involves uploading PDFs, chunking the content, creating embeddings, storing them in a vector database, and using an LLM to generate answers based on retrieved context.

## Step-by-Step Implementation

### 1. **Basic Setup**

```bash
git clone https://github.com/Shubhamsaboo/awesome-llm-apps.git
cd awesome-llm-apps/chat_with_X_tutorials/chat_with_pdf
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

### 2. **Core Components**

- **Document Processing**: Upload PDF → Split into chunks using RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter
- **Embeddings**: Convert chunks to vectors (using FastEmbed or OpenAI embeddings)
- **Vector Database**: Store embeddings in Qdrant for similarity search
- **LLM Integration**: Use OpenAI/Claude/local models to generate answers
- **UI**: Streamlit for interactive chat interface

### 3. **Key Features to Implement**

- PDF upload functionality
- Automatic text chunking and embedding
- Similarity search with threshold filtering
- Context-aware response generation
- Source attribution (show which PDF sections were used)

### 4. **Advanced Options**

**Hybrid Search RAG** (better accuracy):
- Combines semantic search + keyword matching
- Uses reranking (e.g., Cohere) for better context selection
- Fallback to general LLM knowledge when documents don't contain the answer

**Local RAG** (privacy-focused):
- Use local LLMs (Llama, Mistral) instead of API calls
- BGE-M3 embedder with 1024 dimensions
- Runs entirely on your machine (requires sufficient RAM/GPU)

**Voice-Enabled RAG**:
- Add text-to-speech for audio responses
- Multiple voice personality options
- Real-time audio streaming

### 5. **Database Options**

- **Qdrant**: Cloud or self-hosted vector database (recommended)
- **PostgreSQL + Pgvector**: For persistent storage with SQL capabilities
- **SQLite**: For local development/testing

### 6. **Quick Start Example**

```bash
streamlit run chat_pdf.py
```

Then:
1. Upload your PDF document
2. Wait for processing (chunking + embedding)
3. Ask questions about the content
4. Get accurate answers with source citations

## Best Practices

- Use **context window size of 4096** for most use cases
- Implement **automatic fallback to web search** when documents don't contain answers
- Add **query rewriting** for better retrieval accuracy
- Include **source attribution** to show which document sections were used
- Consider **hybrid search** (semantic + keyword) for better results than pure vector search

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/awesome-llm-apps/advanced_llm_apps/chat_with_X_tutorials/chat_with_pdf/README.md > 📄 Chat with PDF]

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/hybrid_search_rag/README.md > 👀 RAG App with Hybrid Search]")]

query: What is Vision RAG? How to do RAG with images?
answer:
## Vision RAG: Multimodal Retrieval-Augmented Generation

**Vision RAG** is a multimodal RAG system that enables you to perform retrieval and question-answering over visual content like images and PDF pages, not just text documents.

### How It Works

Vision RAG follows a two-stage process:

**1. Retrieval Stage:**
- Images (or PDF pages) are converted to base64 strings
- For PDFs: each page is rendered as an image and processed separately
- A multimodal embedding model (like Cohere Embed-4) generates vector embeddings for each image
- When you ask a text question, it's embedded using the same model
- Cosine similarity finds the most relevant image/page for your query

**2. Generation Stage:**
- The retrieved image and your text question are passed to a vision-capable LLM (like Google Gemini 2.5 Flash)
- The model analyzes the image content and generates a context-aware answer
- No OCR required - the model directly interprets visual elements

### Key Capabilities

- **Multimodal Search**: Find relevant images using text queries through semantic similarity
- **Visual Question Answering**: Ask questions about charts, diagrams, infographics, tables
- **PDF Support**: Automatically extracts and processes PDF pages as images
- **Direct Visual Processing**: Handles complex visual elements without separate text extraction

### Use Cases

- Analyze financial charts and extract key figures or trends
- Answer questions about diagrams, flowcharts, or infographics
- Extract information from tables or screenshots without OCR
- Build visual knowledge bases queryable with natural language
- Understand content in multi-page reports and complex visual documents

### Implementation Example

The knowledge base contains a complete implementation using:
- **Cohere Embed-4** for multimodal embeddings
- **Google Gemini 2.5 Flash** for visual question answering
- **Streamlit** for interactive UI
- Support for PNG, JPG, JPEG images and PDF documents

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/vision_rag/README.md > Vision RAG with Cohere Embed-4 🖼️]

[TextBlock(text="## Vision RAG: Multimodal Retrieval-Augmented Generation

**Vision RAG** is a multimodal RAG system that enables you to perform retrieval and question-answering over visual content like images and PDF pages, not just text documents.

### How It Works

Vision RAG follows a two-stage process:

**1. Retrieval Stage:**
- Images (or PDF pages) are converted to base64 strings
- For PDFs: each page is rendered as an image and processed separately
- A multimodal embedding model (like Cohere Embed-4) generates vector embeddings for each image
- When you ask a text question, it's embedded using the same model
- Cosine similarity finds the most relevant image/page for your query

**2. Generation Stage:**
- The retrieved image and your text question are passed to a vision-capable LLM (like Google Gemini 2.5 Flash)
- The model analyzes the image content and generates a context-aware answer
- No OCR required - the model directly interprets visual elements

### Key Capabilities

- **Multimodal Search**: Find relevant images using text queries through semantic similarity
- **Visual Question Answering**: Ask questions about charts, diagrams, infographics, tables
- **PDF Support**: Automatically extracts and processes PDF pages as images
- **Direct Visual Processing**: Handles complex visual elements without separate text extraction

### Use Cases

- Analyze financial charts and extract key figures or trends
- Answer questions about diagrams, flowcharts, or infographics
- Extract information from tables or screenshots without OCR
- Build visual knowledge bases queryable with natural language
- Understand content in multi-page reports and complex visual documents

### Implementation Example

The knowledge base contains a complete implementation using:
- **Cohere Embed-4** for multimodal embeddings
- **Google Gemini 2.5 Flash** for visual question answering
- **Streamlit** for interactive UI
- Support for PNG, JPG, JPEG images and PDF documents

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/vision_rag/README.md > Vision RAG with Cohere Embed-4 🖼️]")]

## Vision RAG: Multimodal Retrieval-Augmented Generation

**Vision RAG** is a multimodal RAG system that enables you to perform retrieval and question-answering over visual content like images and PDF pages, not just text documents.

### How It Works

Vision RAG follows a two-stage process:

**1. Retrieval Stage:**
- Images (or PDF pages) are converted to base64 strings
- For PDFs: each page is rendered as an image and processed separately
- A multimodal embedding model (like Cohere Embed-4) generates vector embeddings for each image
- When you ask a text question, it's embedded using the same model
- Cosine similarity finds the most relevant image/page for your query

**2. Generation Stage:**
- The retrieved image and your text question are passed to a vision-capable LLM (like Google Gemini 2.5 Flash)
- The model analyzes the image content and generates a context-aware answer
- No OCR required - the model directly interprets visual elements

### Key Capabilities

- **Multimodal Search**: Find relevant images using text queries through semantic similarity
- **Visual Question Answering**: Ask questions about charts, diagrams, infographics, tables
- **PDF Support**: Automatically extracts and processes PDF pages as images
- **Direct Visual Processing**: Handles complex visual elements without separate text extraction

### Use Cases

- Analyze financial charts and extract key figures or trends
- Answer questions about diagrams, flowcharts, or infographics
- Extract information from tables or screenshots without OCR
- Build visual knowledge bases queryable with natural language
- Understand content in multi-page reports and complex visual documents

### Implementation Example

The knowledge base contains a complete implementation using:
- **Cohere Embed-4** for multimodal embeddings
- **Google Gemini 2.5 Flash** for visual question answering
- **Streamlit** for interactive UI
- Support for PNG, JPG, JPEG images and PDF documents

query: How to build a RAG chain using LangChain?
answer:
Based on the knowledge base search, here's how to build a RAG chain using LangChain:

## Building a RAG Chain with LangChain

### General Steps

1. **Set up Vector Storage**: Configure a vector database (like Redis, Qdrant) to handle vector data and embeddings.

2. **Use LangChain Integration**: LangChain integrates seamlessly with vector stores. For example:
   - **LangChain + Redis**: Use the [Redis vector store integration](https://python.langchain.com/v0.2/docs/integrations/vectorstores/redis/) to create RAG pipelines
   - **LangChain + Qdrant**: Combine LangChain with Qdrant for document storage and retrieval

3. **Embed and Store Data**: 
   - Convert your documents into vector embeddings using models like BERT or GPT
   - Store embeddings in your vector database for quick retrieval
   - Use document loaders like `WebBaseLoader` to ingest content
   - Split documents using `RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter`

4. **Integrate with a Generative Model**: 
   - Connect a language model (OpenAI, Gemini, etc.) that can leverage retrieved data
   - The model uses vectors from the database to augment its generation process

5. **Query and Generate**: 
   - Implement query logic to retrieve relevant vectors based on input prompts
   - Feed retrieved context into the generative model to produce augmented outputs

### Advanced Patterns

**Agentic RAG with LangGraph**: For more sophisticated workflows, use LangGraph to orchestrate:
- Document retrieval from vector databases
- Relevance assessment of retrieved documents
- Query refinement for better results
- Fallback mechanisms (e.g., web search when no relevant docs found)

**Database Routing**: Use LangChain with intelligent routing to query multiple specialized databases and automatically select the most relevant source.

[TextBlock(text="Based on the knowledge base search, here's how to build a RAG chain using LangChain:

## Building a RAG Chain with LangChain

### General Steps

1. **Set up Vector Storage**: Configure a vector database (like Redis, Qdrant) to handle vector data and embeddings.

2. **Use LangChain Integration**: LangChain integrates seamlessly with vector stores. For example:
   - **LangChain + Redis**: Use the [Redis vector store integration](https://python.langchain.com/v0.2/docs/integrations/vectorstores/redis/) to create RAG pipelines
   - **LangChain + Qdrant**: Combine LangChain with Qdrant for document storage and retrieval

3. **Embed and Store Data**: 
   - Convert your documents into vector embeddings using models like BERT or GPT
   - Store embeddings in your vector database for quick retrieval
   - Use document loaders like `WebBaseLoader` to ingest content
   - Split documents using `RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter`

4. **Integrate with a Generative Model**: 
   - Connect a language model (OpenAI, Gemini, etc.) that can leverage retrieved data
   - The model uses vectors from the database to augment its generation process

5. **Query and Generate**: 
   - Implement query logic to retrieve relevant vectors based on input prompts
   - Feed retrieved context into the generative model to produce augmented outputs

### Advanced Patterns

**Agentic RAG with LangGraph**: For more sophisticated workflows, use LangGraph to orchestrate:
- Document retrieval from vector databases
- Relevance assessment of retrieved documents
- Query refinement for better results
- Fallback mechanisms (e.g., web search when no relevant docs found)

**Database Routing**: Use LangChain with intelligent routing to query multiple specialized databases and automatically select the most relevant source.

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/redis-docs/develop/get-started/rag.md > Benefits of Using Redis for RAG]

[来源: /home/shenzt/ws/my-agent-kb/docs/awesome-llm-apps/rag_tutorials/rag_database_routing/README.md > Technologies Used]")]

Based on the knowledge base search, here's how to build a RAG chain using LangChain:

## Building a RAG Chain with LangChain

### General Steps

1. **Set up Vector Storage**: Configure a vector database (like Redis, Qdrant) to handle vector data and embeddings.

2. **Use LangChain Integration**: LangChain integrates seamlessly with vector stores. For example:
   - **LangChain + Redis**: Use the [Redis vector store integration](https://python.langchain.com/v0.2/docs/integrations/vectorstores/redis/) to create RAG pipelines
   - **LangChain + Qdrant**: Combine LangChain with Qdrant for document storage and retrieval

3. **Embed and Store Data**: 
   - Convert your documents into vector embeddings using models like BERT or GPT
   - Store embeddings in your vector database for quick retrieval
   - Use document loaders like `WebBaseLoader` to ingest content
   - Split documents using `RecursiveCharacterTextSplitter`

4. **Integrate with a Generative Model**: 
   - Connect a language model (OpenAI, Gemini, etc.) that can leverage retrieved data
   - The model uses vectors from the database to augment its generation process

5. **Query and Generate**: 
   - Implement query logic to retrieve relevant vectors based on input prompts
   - Feed retrieved context into the generative model to produce augmented outputs

### Advanced Patterns

**Agentic RAG with LangGraph**: For more sophisticated workflows, use LangGraph to orchestrate:
- Document retrieval from vector databases
- Relevance assessment of retrieved documents
- Query refinement for better results
- Fallback mechanisms (e.g., web search when no relevant docs found)

**Database Routing**: Use LangChain with intelligent routing to query multiple specialized databases and automatically select the most relevant source.
